questions.text: Colour for Nitrous Oxide Cylinder in India is: (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Blue

 

Nitrous oxide is stored in blue color cylinders at a pressure of 760 psi. The standardized color coding system for medical gas cylinders follows Indian Standards adopted on November 24, 1966. 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. White: White shoulders with a black body is the color coding for oxygen cylinders. Oxygen cylinders have a pressure of 2,000 psi and are typically available in various sizes (smallest AA, largest H, with type E commonly mounted on anesthesia machines).

 

Option C. Gray: Gray is the color used for carbon dioxide cylinders. Carbon dioxide was stored at a pressure of 750 psi in liquid form but is no longer commonly used in anesthesia.

 

Option D. Brown: Brown shoulders (combined with black and white) are used for helium-containing mixtures like Heliox, which consists of 79% helium and 21% oxygen stored in black cylinders with brown and white shoulders.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Medical gas cylinder color coding is a critical safety mechanism - nitrous oxide cylinders are distinctively blue, stored at 760 psi, and their contents are measured by weight rather than pressure because the gas exists in liquid form inside the cylinder.

choices.text: Fingers are held in mild extension
Most common involvement is index finger

questions.text: Which of the following statement is true regarding De Quervain's tenosynovitis? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. It affects APL and EPB

 

De Quervain's tenosynovitis involves inflammation of the sheaths of the extensor pollicis brevis (EPB) and abductor pollicis longus (APL) tendons. These tendons run side by side and are located on the radial side of the wrist, traveling through a tunnel (sheath) that can become narrowed due to the inflammation, causing pain especially with thumb and wrist movement.

 

 

Finkelstein's test: On grasping the patient's thumb and quickly abducting the hand ulnar ward, the pain over the radial styloid tip is excruciating. It's the most pathognomonic objective sign but is also seen in other conditions like radial nerve entrapment and arthritis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fingers are held in mild extension: This statement is not typically associated with De Quervain's tenosynovitis. Instead, the thumb is often held in a position of abduction away from the hand to minimize pain. The condition mainly affects the tendons and their sheaths at the base of the thumb, not the fingers.

 

Option C. Most common involvement is index finger: This is incorrect. De Quervain's tenosynovitis primarily affects the base of the thumb. While pain can radiate and might be felt in the nearby areas, including the forearm or even the index finger, the primary site of involvement is the tendons at the thumb's base, not the index finger itself.

 

Option D. Treatment is surgery: While surgery can be an option for De Quervain's tenosynovitis, it is generally considered when conservative treatments fail. Most cases of De Quervain's can be treated conservatively with methods such as: Rest and immobilization using splints, Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) for pain and inflammation , Corticosteroid injections into the tendon sheath to reduce inflammation and Physical therapy.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A patient presents to the emergency department with uniocular diplopia. Examination with oblique illumination shows a golden crescent, while examination with co-axial illumination shows a dark crescent line. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ectopia lentis

 

This patient presents with classic signs of subluxation of the lens (ectopia lentis), which is a partial displacement where the lens is moved sideways but remains behind the pupil. The key diagnostic findings include uniocular diplopia and the characteristic appearance of the lens edge visible as a dark crescent on distant direct (co-axial) illumination and as a shining golden crescent on oblique illumination examination.

 

Subluxation of the lens (a form of ectopia lentis) presents with uniocular diplopia due to partial aphakia. The edge of the subluxated lens is seen as a dark crescent on distant direct (co-axial) ophthalmoscopy and as a shining golden crescent on oblique illumination, exactly matching the clinical findings described.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lenticonus: Incorrect. Lenticonus refers to a cone-shaped elevation of either the anterior or posterior pole of the lens. It presents as an "oil globule" appearance in the center of the red reflex on distant direct ophthalmoscopy, not as a crescent. It doesn't typically cause uniocular diplopia.

 

Option B. Coloboma: Incorrect. Coloboma of the lens appears as a notch in the lower quadrant of the equator of the lens. While it is a structural abnormality, it doesn't cause the characteristic golden/dark crescent sign described, nor is it typically associated with uniocular diplopia.

 

Option C. Microspherophakia: Incorrect. In microspherophakia, the lens is spherical in shape and small in size. While microspherophakia can be associated with lens displacement, the primary finding would be the small, spherical lens rather than just the crescentic signs described.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Subluxated lens (ectopia lentis) has pathognomonic findings of uniocular diplopia and visualization of the lens edge as a dark crescent on co-axial illumination and a golden crescent on oblique illumination.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman presented with claudication in the forearm, transient loss of vision, and abdominal pain. Femoral pulses were weak. Fundus examination revealed retinal hemorrhages. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Takayasu arteritis

 

Takayasu arteritis, also known as "pulseless disease," is a large vessel vasculitis that primarily affects the aorta and its major branches. It is more common in young Asian females under 40 years old. The clinical presentation includes claudication (typically in the upper limbs due to subclavian artery involvement), weak pulses (particularly in the extremities), and symptoms resulting from ischemia in various organs (e.g., transient loss of vision due to carotid or vertebral artery involvement, abdominal pain due to mesenteric artery involvement).

 

The combination of weak femoral pulses, claudication in the forearm, and retinal hemorrhages is characteristic of Takayasu arteritis. This condition can lead to narrowing or occlusion of major arteries, causing diminished blood flow to the affected regions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Polyarteritis nodosa: Polyarteritis nodosa (PAN) is a medium vessel vasculitis that can cause abdominal pain, claudication, and other systemic symptoms, but it does not typically affect the large vessels and therefore would not explain the weak femoral pulses. PAN is often associated with hepatitis B infection.

 

Option B. Thromboangiitis obliterans: Thromboangiitis obliterans (Buerger's disease) typically affects young male smokers and primarily involves the small and medium arteries of the extremities. It can cause claudication and ischemic symptoms in the limbs but does not typically cause weak femoral pulses or retinal hemorrhages.

 

Option D. Microscopic polyangiitis: Microscopic polyangiitis (MPA) is a small vessel vasculitis that often presents with symptoms related to kidney and lung involvement (e.g., rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis and pulmonary hemorrhage). It does not typically present with claudication or weak pulses in the large vessels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Takayasu arteritis should be considered in young women presenting with symptoms of large vessel occlusion, such as claudication, weak pulses, and ischemic symptoms in various organs. It is characterized by the involvement of the aorta and its major branches, and the diagnosis can be confirmed with imaging studies like CT angiogram or conventional angiography.

questions.text: Which of the following eye sign is given in the image? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tache noire

 

The image depicts a condition known as Tache noire, characterized by a triangular brownish discoloration on the sclera. This occurs due to the deposition of bacteria and dust, usually within 3 to 4 hours after death. Tache noire is a postmortem change observed in the eyes of the deceased when the eyelids are partially open, leading to drying of the exposed sclera.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Kevorkian sign: This sign involves the fragmentation of blood in blood vessels into columns due to the loss of blood pressure after death. The characteristic appearance is shown in the image.

 

 

Option C. Corneal changes: These involve alterations in the cornea, such as clouding, that occur after death. However, the given image does not show corneal clouding but rather a specific discoloration indicative of Tache noire.

 

Option D. Vitreous humour changes: These refer to alterations in the vitreous humour of the eye postmortem, such as changes in its consistency or color. The image does not depict such changes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tache noire is a postmortem change characterized by a triangular brownish discoloration on the sclera due to drying and deposition of bacteria and dust, typically occurring within a few hours after death.

questions.text: A 19-year-old patient presents with generalized edema (anasarca). Laboratory tests reveal proteinuria of 4.5 g/day, hypoalbuminemia, and hyperlipidemia. What is the recommended treatment for this condition? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Steroids

 

Explanation:

 

This patient has nephrotic syndrome, characterized by:

 

  • Proteinuria >3.5 g/day
  • Hypoalbuminemia
  • Generalized edema (anasarca)
  • Hyperlipidemia

 

In young adults and children, one of the most common causes is Minimal Change Disease (MCD), which is highly responsive to corticosteroids.

 

First-line therapy:

 

  • High-dose steroids (prednisone 1 mg/kg/day) for 4–8 weeks
  • 80-90% remission rate

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IV albumin: Provides temporary relief but does not treat the underlying disease

 

Option B. Cyclophosphamide: Reserved for steroid-resistant or frequently relapsing nephrotic syndrome

 

Option D. Steroids and cyclophosphamide: Combination therapy is not needed initially. Can be used for immune mediated disorders like lupus nehritis as a part of induction therapy. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nephrotic syndrome in children (and some times in young adults) is most commonly due to Minimal Change Disease and is highly responsive to corticosteroids.

questions.text: If percentage of thymine residues in DNA is 28%. what is the percentage of cytosine?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 22%

 

Explanation:

 

  • By Chargaff’s rule, number of purines equal the number of pyrimidines in a double stranded DNA. So, amount of Adenine = Thymine. As Thymine is given as 28%, so total A+T is 56%.
  • Now also, amount of Guanine = Cytosine, as they pair with each other by three hydrogen bonds.
    Remaining 44% (100-56) equally distributed in 22% each for guanine and cytosine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In DNA, thymine (T) always pairs with adenine (A), forming a complementary base pair. Similarly, cytosine (C) always pairs with guanine (G). The base pairing in DNA is always complementary, and the total percentage of purines (adenine + guanine) equals the total percentage of pyrimidines (thymine + cytosine).

questions.text: A young child complained to his parents that he was touched inappropriately by a neighbor.  On examination by a doctor in the OPD, he complained of pain when touched in the perianal area. On subjecting the specimen from the perianal region to a test, it produces yellow rhombic crystals of spermine pirate. What is the test done? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Barberio test

 

As the crystals are seen under the microscope, this indicates that it is a microchemical test.

 

Microchemical tests for Semen: Florence and Barberio test (Both are presumptive tests)

 

Microchemical tests for Blood: Teichmann’s and Takayama test (Both are confirmatory tests)

 

Barberio’s test

 

  • Reagent: Picric Acid
  • Component of semen detected: Spermine (secreted from prostate gland)
  • Shape of crystals: Yellow needle shaped crystals of spermine picrate.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Florence test

 

  • Reagent: KI + I2 + H2O
  • Component of semen detected: Coline (secreted from seminal vesicles)
  • Shape of crystals: Dark Brown rhombic crystals of choline iodide (resemble hemin but larger than hemin crystals)

 

 

Option C. Hemochromogen (Takayama) test:

 

  • Reagent: NaOH + pyridine + glucose
  • Pink feathery crystals of hemochromogen (reduced alkaline hematin)

 

 

Option D. Hemin (Teichmann’s) test:

 

  • Reagent: NaCl + acetic acid
  • Brownish-black rhombic crystals of hematin chloride
  • Negative in old stains or washed or treated with chemicals

 

 

Educational Objective

 

The Barberio test detects the presence of spermine from semen by forming yellow needle-shaped crystals of spermine picrate, making it the correct test for the described scenario.

questions.text: A diabetic patient's blood sample was taken in a grey top vacutainer. Which of the following is added for the correct estimate of blood glucose? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sodium fluoride

 

Explanation:

 

For accurate measurement of blood glucose levels in diabetic patients, the blood sample is collected in a grey top vacutainer containing sodium fluoride. Sodium fluoride acts as a glycolysis inhibitor, preventing the breakdown of glucose by red blood cells. This ensures that the glucose levels in the sample remain stable until the analysis is performed, providing an accurate representation of the patient's blood glucose concentration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sodium citrate is used as an anticoagulant and is present in blue top vacutainers, which are typically used for coagulation studies and not for glucose estimation.

 

Option C. EDTA (Ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid) is an anticoagulant used in lavender top vacutainers, which are commonly used for complete blood count (CBC) and other hematological tests, but not for glucose estimation.

 

Option D. Heparin is an anticoagulant found in green top vacutainers, which are used for various biochemical tests, but not specifically for glucose estimation in diabetic patients.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sodium fluoride, present in grey top vacutainers, inhibits glycolysis and prevents the breakdown of glucose, ensuring an accurate measurement of blood glucose levels in diabetic patients.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis based on the given image? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Aberrant right subclavian artery

 

The CT scan image provided shows an anatomical variant where there is an extra vessel coursing behind the esophagus towards the right side. Normally, there are three major arch arteries visible at this level. However, in this image, an additional vessel is seen, which is characteristic of an aberrant right subclavian artery.

 

The aberrant right subclavian artery is an anatomical variation where the right subclavian artery arises as the fourth branch of the aortic arch and passes posterior to the esophagus. This can lead to a condition known as dysphagia lusoria, where the esophagus is compressed by the artery, causing difficulty in swallowing (dysphagia).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Right sided aortic arch: This condition involves the aortic arch itself being positioned on the right side, which is not indicated by the presence of an extra vessel behind the esophagus in this image.

 

Option C. Tracheal diverticulum: A tracheal diverticulum would appear as an air-filled outpouching from the trachea. The image does not show any such outpouching or abnormality of the trachea.

 

Option D. Esophageal duplication: This is a rare congenital condition where a duplicated segment of the esophagus is present. The image does not show an additional lumen or any signs indicative of esophageal duplication.

 

Educational Objective:

 

An aberrant right subclavian artery is an anatomical variant where the artery arises as the fourth branch of the aortic arch and courses posterior to the esophagus, often leading to dysphagia lusoria due to esophageal compression.

questions.text: A cephalic index of 82 belongs to which racial group? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mongoloid

 

Explanation:

 

Cephalic Index (CI) Formula:

 

Cephalic index =  (Maximum breadth of skull/Maximum length of skull) × 100 


Classification based on cephalic index:

 

  • Dolichocephalic (70-75): Found in Aryans, Negroes, Aborigines (ANA)
  • Mesaticephalic (75-80): Found in Europeans (Caucasians), Indians, Chinese
  • Brachycephalic (80-85): Found in Mongoloids 

 

A cephalic index of 82 falls in the brachycephalic range, which is characteristic of Mongoloid populations

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Negroid: Incorrect. Negroid skulls are Dolichocephalic (CI 70- 75), meaning they have a long, narrow skull

​

Option C. Caucasian: Incorrect. Caucasian skulls are Mesaticephalic (CI: 75-80), meaning they have a medium-sized skull

​

Option D. Chinese: Incorrect. Chinese skulls are Mesaticephalic (CI: 75-80), meaning they have a medium-sized skull

​

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following anatomical landmarks is not commonly used for identifying the facial nerve trunk during parotid surgery? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Inferior belly of omohyoid muscle

 

The omohyoid muscle is a thin, flat muscle in the anterior neck, and it has no direct anatomical relation to the facial nerve trunk. Therefore, it is not used as a landmark to identify the facial nerve trunk during surgeries.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Retrograde dissection from distal branch: This involves tracing the facial nerve branches from their more distal and superficial positions back towards their origin at the main trunk of the facial nerve. This is a common technique used by surgeons, especially when there is difficulty locating the main trunk due to factors like inflammation, previous surgery, or anatomical variations.

 

Option B. Tragal pointer: It is a small cartilaginous projection at the anterior margin of the external auditory meatus, from the tragus of the ear. The main trunk of the facial nerve typically lies about 1 cm deep and slightly inferior to the tragal pointer, making it a reliable landmark to locate the facial nerve trunk during parotid gland surgeries.

 

Option D. Posterior belly of digastric: The posterior belly of the digastric muscle is another important anatomical landmark in parotid surgeries. The main trunk of the facial nerve is usually found superficial and medial to the posterior belly of the digastric muscle. This muscle serves as a consistent landmark to help in locating the facial nerve trunk.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Methods to identify the facial nerve trunk during parotid surgeries:

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient with a history of chronic alcohol use presents with complaints of confusion and ataxia. Upon examination, nystagmus and sixth nerve palsy were observed. What is the likely diagnosis?  (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Wernicke's Encephalopathy

 

The presentation of a 40-year-old patient with a history of chronic alcohol use, who is experiencing confusion, ataxia, nystagmus, and sixth nerve palsy, is highly suggestive of Wernicke's Encephalopathy. This is caused by thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency, commonly seen in individuals with chronic alcohol use. Wernicke's Encephalopathy is characterized by the classic triad of confusion, oculomotor dysfunction (such as nystagmus and cranial nerve palsies), and ataxia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Korsakoff Syndrome: This is a chronic neuropsychiatric syndrome that often follows Wernicke's Encephalopathy. It is characterized by severe memory impairment, confabulation, and behavioral changes but lacks the acute neurological symptoms such as nystagmus and ataxia seen in Wernicke's Encephalopathy.

 

Option C. Delirium Tremens: This is a severe form of alcohol withdrawal characterized by delirium, tremors, agitation, hallucinations, and autonomic instability. While confusion is common, the specific neurological findings of nystagmus and sixth nerve palsy are more indicative of Wernicke's Encephalopathy.

 

Option D. De Clerambault Syndrome: Also known as erotomania, this is a delusional disorder characterized by the belief that another person is in love with the individual. It is unrelated to the symptoms presented in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Wernicke’s encephalopathy is caused by thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency, which is common in individuals with chronic alcohol use due to poor nutritional intake and absorption. Treatment include high dose of parenteral thiamine. Ophthalmoplegia responds first to the treatment, ataxia doesnt improve completely in almost 50% of cases.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 277.

questions.text: Which of the following factor is not derived from an ABG analysis directly? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bicarbonate

 

Explanation:

 

Arterial blood gas (ABG) analysis is a critical test in clinical settings that measures the levels of oxygen (PO2), carbon dioxide (PCO2), and the pH of the blood. These parameters are directly measured by the ABG machine. However, bicarbonate (HCO3-) is not directly measured by the ABG machine; instead, it is calculated using the Henderson-Hasselbalch equation, which involves the measured pH and PCO2 values.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. PO2: The partial pressure of oxygen (PO2) is directly measured by the ABG machine, providing vital information about oxygenation status.

 

Option C. PCO2: The partial pressure of carbon dioxide (PCO2) is also directly measured by the ABG machine and indicates the level of CO2 in the blood, reflecting respiratory function.

 

Option D. pH: The pH level of the blood, which indicates its acidity or alkalinity, is directly measured by the ABG machine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

ABG analysis measures the levels of oxygen (PO2), carbon dioxide (PCO2), and the pH of the blood, not bicarbonate.

questions.text: A thyroid biopsy shows follicular cells with eosinophilic cytoplasm and extracellular amyloid depositions.  In which of the following thyroid conditions is this finding commonly seen? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Medullary carcinoma

 

Medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC) is characterized by the presence of extracellular amyloid deposits, which are composed of calcitonin. This is a distinctive feature of MTC that helps differentiate it from other thyroid cancers. MTC originates from the parafollicular C cells of the thyroid gland, which normally produce calcitonin. Amyloid deposition is a key diagnostic feature of MTC and appears as an extracellular pinkish material that stains positive with Congo red and shows apple-green birefringence under polarized light.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hurthle cell carcinoma: Incorrect. While Hurthle cell carcinoma does feature cells with abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm (due to mitochondrial accumulation), it does not typically show extracellular amyloid deposition. Hurthle cells are characterized by their large size, granular eosinophilic cytoplasm, and prominent nucleoli.

 

 

Option C. Papillary carcinoma: Incorrect. Papillary thyroid carcinoma is characterized by papillary architecture and distinctive nuclear features (orphan Annie nuclei, nuclear grooves, and pseudoinclusions). While calcifications may be present (psammoma bodies), extracellular amyloid deposition is not a feature of papillary carcinoma.

 

Option D. Anaplastic carcinoma: Incorrect. Anaplastic thyroid carcinoma is a highly aggressive undifferentiated tumor characterized by pleomorphic giant cells, spindle cells, and marked nuclear atypia. It does not show the organized pattern of amyloid deposition seen in medullary carcinoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Medullary Thyroid Cancer

 

  • Only thyroid cancer that arises from parafollicular cells known as 'C cells.
  • Gene association: RET Gene mutation.
  • Tumor markers: Calcitonin and Carcinoembryonic
    • Antigen; CEA in calcitonin negative cancer
  • Acal: Amyloid (Congo red positive)
  • Histology: Polygonal cells with/without Amyloid deposition.
  • Electon microscopy: Neurosecretory granules.

 

 

Clinical features: due to secretion of ACTH (Cushing syndrome) and VIP (Diarrhoea)

 

Variants → Sporadic (Unilateral solitary mass) OR Familial (Bilateral & Multicentric)

questions.text: Thiazide works on ________ in DCT:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Na+ Cl- Cotransporter

 

Explanation:

 

Thiazide diuretics act specifically on the distal convoluted tubule (DCT) of the nephron. They inhibit the sodium-chloride (Na+ Cl-) cotransporter, which is responsible for the reabsorption of sodium and chloride from the lumen of the DCT into the cells. This inhibition leads to increased excretion of sodium and chloride, resulting in diuresis (increased urine production).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Na+ K+ 2Cl- Cotransporter: This cotransporter is located in the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle, not in the DCT. Therefore, thiazide diuretics do not act on this transporter.

 

Option B. ENaC Channels: Epithelial sodium channels (ENaC) are found in the collecting duct (CD), not the DCT. Thiazide diuretics do not affect these channels.

 

Option D. Na+ H+ Antiport: This antiport mechanism is not the target of thiazide diuretics. They do not act on this transport system in the DCT.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thiazide diuretics inhibit the Na+ Cl- cotransporter in the distal convoluted tubule, leading to increased excretion of sodium and chloride and resulting in diuresis.

questions.text: A 67-year-old female with a history of diabetes mellitus underwent a prosthetic valve replacement surgery 4 weeks ago. She now presents with fever, fatigue, and a new murmur on examination. Blood cultures reveal the causative organism. Which is the most likely causative agent? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Staph epidermidis

 

This is a case of early prosthetic valve endocarditis (PVE) occurring within 4 weeks of valve replacement surgery. Staphylococcus epidermidis is the most common causative organism in early PVE, characterized by its occurrence within one year of surgery. The mnemonic "E for Early, E for Epidermidis" helps remember this association. Additionally, S. epidermidis is also the overall most common cause of prosthetic valve endocarditis regardless of timing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Enterococcus: While it can cause endocarditis, it is not the most common cause of early prosthetic valve endocarditis. It is more commonly associated with nosocomial urinary tract infections.

 

Option C. Staphylococcus aureus: S. aureus commonly seen in native valve endocarditis, particularly in patients with underlying valve disease.

 

Option D. Streptococcus viridans: This organism is typically associated with late prosthetic valve endocarditis (occurring after one year of valve replacement).

 

Educational Objective:

 

 Staphylococcus epidermidis is the most common causative organism in early prosthetic valve endocarditis (occurring within one year of valve replacement) and is also the overall most common cause of prosthetic valve endocarditis.

questions.text: Laryngismus stridulus is due to deficiency of: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vitamin D

 

Laryngismus stridulus, also known as spasmodic croup, is characterized by sudden onset of apnea and a loud stridor due to respiratory obstruction caused by laryngospasm. This condition is often associated with rickets, which is caused by a deficiency of Vitamin D. Rickets leads to softening and weakening of the bones in children, and it can also cause disturbances in the metabolism of calcium and phosphorus, leading to neuromuscular irritability, which in turn can result in laryngospasm.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin A: Vitamin A deficiency primarily affects the eyes, leading to conditions such as night blindness and xerophthalmia. It does not cause laryngismus stridulus.

 

Option C. Vitamin E: Vitamin E deficiency is rare and typically presents with neurological symptoms due to its role as an antioxidant. It does not cause laryngismus stridulus.

 

Option D. Vitamin K: Vitamin K deficiency leads to bleeding disorders because of its role in the synthesis of clotting factors. It is not associated with laryngismus stridulus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Laryngismus stridulus, characterized by sudden respiratory obstruction and stridor, is associated with rickets caused by Vitamin D deficiency. Recognizing the link between Vitamin D deficiency and laryngismus stridulus is important for diagnosis and treatment.

questions.text: Jackson Rees circuit is used in: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pediatric controlled ventilation

 

Jackson Rees circuit (also known as Mapleson F circuit) is specifically designed for:

 

  • Pediatric patients
  • Can be used for both spontaneous and controlled ventilation in children
  • It's a modification of the Ayre's T-piece with an open-ended bag
  • This circuit is ideal for pediatric anesthesia due to its low resistance and minimal dead space

 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Adult controlled ventilation: Not appropriate as Jackson Rees circuit is designed for pediatric patients. Adults require circuits with larger volumes and different configurations.

 

Option C. Obstetric ventilation: Obstetric patients require specialized circuits that can deliver high flow rates and manage rapid changes in ventilation demands.

 

Option D. Cardiac patients: Cardiac patients typically require precise control over ventilation parameters, which is better achieved with more sophisticated circuits.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Jackson Rees circuit (Mapleson F) is specifically designed and used for pediatric anesthesia, suitable for both spontaneous and controlled ventilation.

questions.text: The wavelength of the laser (in nanometers) used for shaping the cornea in refractive surgery is? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 193 nm

 

The excimer laser used for refractive surgery procedures like LASIK and PRK operates at a wavelength of 193 nanometers, which is in the ultraviolet (UV) range. This specific wavelength is produced by excited dimers (hence the name "excimer") of argon and fluoride gases. The 193 nm wavelength is precisely absorbed by corneal tissue, allowing for accurate photoablation of the corneal stroma without thermal damage to surrounding tissues.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 451 nm: This is incorrect. 451 nm falls in the visible blue light spectrum and is not used for corneal refractive surgery. This wavelength would not provide the precise photoablative effect needed to reshape the cornea without thermal damage.

 

Option C. 532 nm: This is incorrect. The 532 nm wavelength is in the visible green light spectrum and is typically used in some ophthalmic laser procedures like selective laser trabeculoplasty (SLT) for glaucoma treatment, not for corneal refractive surgery.

 

Option D. 1064 nm: This is incorrect. The 1064 nm wavelength is in the near-infrared spectrum and is used in Nd: YAG lasers for posterior capsulotomy after cataract surgery or for peripheral iridotomy in angle-closure glaucoma. The femtosecond laser used to create corneal flaps in LASIK uses wavelengths around 1054 nm, but this is distinct from the excimer laser that actually reshapes the cornea.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The 193 nm ultraviolet excimer laser provides the precise ablation characteristics needed for corneal refractive procedures, allowing for accurate tissue removal without thermal damage to surrounding structures - a critical factor in achieving predictable visual outcomes in refractive surgery.

questions.text: Identify the type of transport across the cell membrane represented below? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Facilitated diffusion

 

Explanation:

 

The image depicts the process of facilitated diffusion. This type of transport involves the use of carrier proteins embedded in the cell membrane to help molecules that cannot readily diffuse through the lipid bilayer move across the membrane, down their concentration gradient, without the expenditure of cellular energy (ATP).

 

  • Facilitated Diffusion: This process helps molecules move from an area of higher concentration to one of lower concentration via specific carrier proteins. It is a passive transport method since it does not require energy from ATP but relies on the concentration gradient.
  • Carrier Proteins: These proteins undergo a change in shape to transport molecules across the membrane. They are specific to the substances they transport, ensuring selective and regulated transport into and out of the cell.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Simple Diffusion: Involves the movement of molecules directly through the phospholipid bilayer without the assistance of membrane proteins, driven solely by their concentration gradient.

 

Option C. Primary Active Transport: Requires ATP to move substances against their concentration gradient via pumps.

 

Option D. Secondary Active Transport: Also known as co-transport, uses the gradient of one molecule to move another molecule against its gradient, indirectly using energy but not directly using ATP.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following vascular events is most closely associated with pure word deafness? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Stroke involving the middle cerebral artery

 

Explanation:

 

Pure word deafness results from damage to the auditory association cortex in the temporal lobe. The inferior division of the middle cerebral artery supplies the temporal cortex and Wernicke's area. Pure word deafness presents with intact fluency, lost comprehension specifically to spoken language, lost repetition, but intact naming - a distinctive pattern caused by focal damage to auditory language processing pathways, which are within the MCA territory.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Stroke involving the posterior cerebral artery: PCA strokes typically cause visual field defects, and when affecting the dominant hemisphere may cause alexia without agraphia, but not pure word deafness as the PCA supplies primarily visual processing areas.

 

Option C. Aneurysm of the vertebral artery: Vertebral artery lesions typically cause lateral medullary syndrome with symptoms like vertigo, ipsilateral facial sensory loss, and contralateral body sensory loss, not language disorders.

 

Option D. Aneurysm of the basilar artery: Basilar artery lesions produce brainstem syndromes with cranial nerve palsies and long tract signs, not selective auditory comprehension deficits.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 Pure word deafness is a distinctive language disorder involving selective impairment of spoken language comprehension with preserved other language functions, resulting from lesions to the temporal auditory processing areas in the middle cerebral artery territory.

questions.text: A patient with a previous history of myocardial infarction and ventricular arrhythmia is on treatment for the same since a few months. He developed fatigue, dyspnea, and weight gain. He had also developed pulmonary fibrosis. Which of the following drugs is responsible for the above-mentioned side effects? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Amiodarone

 

The drug that is responsible for the above-mentioned side effects is amiodarone.

 

Amiodarone

 

→ Longest acting [t1/2 → > 3 weeks] anti-arrhythmic drug

 

→ MOA →

  1. Na+ channel Blocker
  2. β-Blocker (Non-competitive)
  3. K+ channel Blocker [Main action]
  4. Calcium channel blocker

 

→ Indicated in all arrhythmias except Torsades de pointes

 

→ Adverse effect of amiodarone:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Atenolol: Atenolol is a Selective Beta 1 Blocker. C/I in Bradycardia, AV Block and Acute CHF. It is used in HTN, Classical angina, MI, Chronic CHF, Arrythmia

 

Option C. Aspirin: Aspirin is only irreversible COX Inhibitor, anti-platelet drug. C/I in child with viral infection (Due to Reye’s syndrome). Can cause Hyperuricemia at therapeutic doses - avoid in gout

 

Option D. Spironolactone: Spironolactone is classified under potassium-sparing diuretic. Promotes sodium diuresis but maintains the body's potassium levels. C/I in patients with hyperkalemia. Can cause gynecomastia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Amiodarone is associated with a range of serious side effects, including pulmonary fibrosis, thyroid dysfunction, liver toxicity, and photosensitivity.

questions.text: A patient with traumatic paraplegia due to injury at the thoracic cord level of T3 is found to have a blood pressure of 210/120 mm Hg. What should be the initial management? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Nifedipine

 

This patient is exhibiting autonomic dysreflexia, a life-threatening emergency seen in patients with spinal cord injuries at or above T6. The T3 level injury in this patient has disrupted descending inhibitory pathways that normally regulate sympathetic outflow. When a noxious stimulus occurs below the level of injury (often bladder distention, bowel impaction, or skin irritation), there is massive sympathetic discharge resulting in severe hypertension. Immediate blood pressure control with a rapidly-acting antihypertensive agent like nifedipine is essential to prevent complications such as stroke, seizures, or myocardial infarction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Subcutaneous LMWH: While deep venous thrombosis prophylaxis is important in spinal cord injury patients, LMWH does not address the immediate life-threatening hypertension from autonomic dysreflexia.

 

Option B. Steroids: Steroids have no role in the acute management of autonomic dysreflexia. They were previously used in acute spinal cord injury but are not indicated for this hypertensive emergency.

 

Option D. Normal saline/Dextrose: Intravenous fluids would not help and may worsen hypertension in autonomic dysreflexia. Blood pressure reduction, not volume expansion, is the priority.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Autonomic dysreflexia is a medical emergency in patients with spinal cord injuries at or above T6 requiring immediate blood pressure control with rapid-acting antihypertensives while simultaneously identifying and removing the triggering stimulus.

questions.text: A patient experienced difficulty switching from one movement to another, along with uncontrollable hand movements. Identify the abnormality: (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Dysdiadochokinesia

 

Explanation: 

 

Dysdiadochokinesia refers to the inability to perform rapid alternating movements smoothly and refers to cerebellar dysfunction. From the clinical presentation described - difficulty switching movements and uncontrollable hand movements - this is a classic case of dysdiadochokinesia. 

 

  • Di: two
  • Docho: alternate
  • Kinesis: movement 

 

This is one of the key signs of cerebellar disease, specifically affecting the coordination of voluntary movements.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Intentional tremor: This occurs when a patient is performing a purposeful action and gets worse as they approach the target. 

 

Option C. Metamorphosis: This is seen in lesions of the amygdala or temporal lobe and refers to an uncontrollable urge to respond to every stimulus. It's not related to movement disorders.

 

Option D. Resting tremor: This is primarily seen in Parkinson's disease and occurs when the affected body part is at rest. 

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Dysdiadochokinesia is a cerebellar sign characterized by inability to perform rapid alternating movements smoothly.
